title: Running with GLMMs in R
text:
Preface
This is a Quarto book.

title: 1  Chapter 1: Foundations of GLMMs
text:
1.1 Applications
Generalized linear mixed models (GLMMs) extend traditional linear models by incorporating both fixed and random effects.1 These models are particularly useful in ecology, epidemiology, and other fields where data have hierarchical or nested structure.2
In the context of model comparison, the coefficient of determination ( R^2 ) has been adapted for GLMMs by Nakagawa and Schielzeth.3
Let us now consider a study on lizard movement and thermoregulation, where hierarchical modeling played a key role in capturing population-level variation.4
Bayesian approaches to GLMMs have gained popularity due to their flexibility and ability to handle complex hierarchical structures.5

title: 1  Chapter 1: Foundations of GLMMs
text:
1.1.1 Model Comparison
A second reference to the same foundational text confirms its continued relevance.6

title: 1  Chapter 1: Foundations of GLMMs
text:
1.2 Conclusion
GLMMs are not a panacea, but when applied thoughtfully, they enable sophisticated modeling of structured data.7




Gelman, Andrew, and Jennifer Hill. Data Analysis Using Regression and Multilevel/Hierarchical Models. Cambridge University Press, 2007.


Johnson, Emily R. “Bayesian Hierarchical Models for Species Distribution.” PhD thesis, University of British Columbia, 2020.


McCulloch, Charles E, Shayle R Searle, and John M Neuhaus. “Generalized Linear Mixed Models.” In Encyclopedia of Statistics in Behavioral Science, edited by Brian S Everitt and David C Howell, 641–44. Wiley, 2008.


Nakagawa, Shinichi, and Holger Schielzeth. “A General and Simple Method for Obtaining R² from Generalized Linear Mixed-Effects Models.” Methods in Ecology and Evolution 4, no. 2 (2013): 133–42.


Russell, Anthony P., and Aaron M. Bauer. “Lizards in a Warming World Dataset.” Dryad Digital Repository, 2017. https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.xxxxx.

title: 2  Introduction
text:
This is a book created from markdown and executable code.
In their discussion of “Why we avoid the term ‘random effects.’”1 Gelman and Hill note that in their framework all regression parameters are ‘random,’. The address this again in Chapter 10.2
Nakagawa and Schielzeth provide R² estimates for GLMMs.3

title: 3  Summary
text:
In summary, this book has no content whatsoever.
